1.Name: Replace existing lighting with T8 upgrade (0.7W/sf)
1.Description: Replace existing lighting to T8 lamps with 7.5 W/m2 [2.38 Btu/h/ft2]. T8 lamps use fewer watts, release less heat and produce more lumens compared with older fixtures. A retrofit kit is recommended for converting ballasts. Replacement may improve lighting quality.

2.Name: Replace existing lighting with T5 upgrade (0.67W/sf)
2.Description: Replace existing lighting to T5 lamps with 7.2 W/m2 [2.28 Btu/h/ft2]. T5 lamps use fewer watts, release less heat and produce more lumens compared with older fixtures. A retrofit kit is recommended for converting ballasts. Replacement may improve lighting quality.

3.Name: Replace existing lighting with LED upgrade (0.6W/sf)
3.Description: Replace existing lighting to LEDs with 6.5 W/m2 [2.38 Btu/h/ft2]. LEDs consume less power and last longer than fluorescent lamps. A retrofit kit is recommended for converting ballasts. Replacement may improve lighting quality.

4.Name: Single zone rooftop unit efficiency upgrade (SEER 12.5)
4.Description: Replace rooftop HVAC unit with a higher efficiency single zone rooftop unit (SEER 12.5). This is for cooling only and includes standard controls, curb, and economizer.

5.Name: Single zone rooftop unit efficiency upgrade (SEER 14)
5.Description: Replace rooftop HVAC unit with a higher efficiency single zone rooftop unit (SEER 14). This is for cooling only and includes standard controls, curb, and economizer.

6.Name: Packaged Rooftop VAV Unit Efficiency Upgrade (SEER 12.5)
6.Description: Replace RTU with higher-efficiency unit with a reheat, SEER 12.5 Cooling only; include standard controls, curb, and economizer.

7.Name: Packaged Rooftop VAV Unit Efficiency Upgrade (SEER 14)
7.Description: Replace RTU with higher-efficiency unit with reheat, SEER 14. Cooling only; include standard controls, curb, and economizer.

8.Name: Gas Furnace Efficiency Upgrade (AFUE 92)
8.Description: Replace existing heating system with high efficiency gas furnace with an annual fuel utilization efficiency of 92 (AFUE 92)

9.Name: Gas Boiler Efficiency Upgrade (AFUE 92)
9.Description: Replace existing heating system with high efficiency gas boiler with an annual fuel utilization efficiency of 92 (AFUE 92)

10.Name: Gas Furnace Efficiency Upgrade (AFUE 95)
10.Description: Replace existing heating system with high efficiency gas furnace with an annual fuel utilization efficiency of 95 (AFUE 95)

11.Name: Gas Boiler Efficiency Upgrade (AFUE 95)
11.Description: Replace existing heating system with high efficiency gas boiler with an annual fuel utilization efficiency of 95 (AFUE 95)

12.Name: Add Economizer
12.Description: Install economizer for existing HVAC system (includes temperature sensors, damper motors, motor controls, and dampers).

13.Name: Add Air Sealing to Seal Leaks
13.Description: Air sealing can reduce cold drafts and help improve thermal comfort in buildings. Air sealing is a weatherization strategy which will change the air exchange rate and IAQ.

14.Name: Plug Load Efficiency Upgrade (25% efficient from Baseline)
14.Description: Eliminate or unplug unnecessary equipment and replace equipment with more energy efficient versions, to reduce the plug-load power density (achieve 25% more efficient from baseline).

15.Name: Use Plug Load Controller (30% efficient from Baseline)
15.Description: Connect plug loads to a smart plug strip with some or all of the following functions:  Occupancy sensing, load sensing, timers, remote control.

16.Name: Reroof and Roof with Insulation (R24.83)
16.Description: Demolish existing roof, install insulation (R24.83) and reroof to reduced unwanted heat gain/loss. This measure is most applicable to older roofs.

17.Name: Apply Cool Roof Coating with Reflectivity (0.4)
17.Description: Apply a cool roof coating, a monolithic, fully adhered roofing membrane, with a reflectivity (0.4) which can deliver a high solar reflectance and high thermal emittance, commonly associated with a white roof. An existing dark roof is a prerequisite.

18.Name: Efficiency Upgrade of the Gas Storage Water Heater (0.93)
18.Description: Replace the existing service hot water heater with more efficient gas storage unit, with better insulation, heat traps and more efficient burners to increase overall efficiency of (0.93).

19.Name: Apply Wall Insulation (R15)
19.Description: Apply blown-fiberglass insulation (R15) to wall cavity will help maintain the thermal comfort. Insulation provides resistance to heat flow, taking less energy to heat/cool the space.

20.Name: Apply Wall Insulation (R19)
20.Description: Apply blown-fiberglass insulation (R19) to wall cavity will help maintain the thermal comfort. Insulation provides resistance to heat flow, taking less energy to heat/cool the space.

21.Name: Apply Wall Insulation (R21)
21.Description: Apply blown-fiberglass insulation (R21) to wall cavity will help maintain the thermal comfort. Insulation provides resistance to heat flow, taking less energy to heat/cool the space.

22.Name: Replace fixed-window to U-factor (0.29) and SHGC (0.2)
22.Description: Replace existing window glass and frame with high performance windows by changing the U-factor and SHGC of the window material. The U-factor is a measure of thermal transmittance and SHGC stands for Solar Heat Gain Coefficient, values taken as 0.29 Btu/(hÂ·ft2Â·Â°F), SHGC: 0.2. The SHGC and U-factor are 20% below Title 24 values.

23.Name: Replace fixed-window to U-factor (0.25) and SHGC (0.18)
23.Description: Replace existing window glass and frame with high performance windows by changing the U-factor and SHGC of the window material. The U-factor is a measure of thermal transmittance and SHGC stands for Solar Heat Gain Coefficient, values taken as 0.25 Btu/(hÂ·ft2Â·Â°F), SHGC: 0.18. The SHGC and U-factor are 30% below Title 24 values.

24.Name: Replace storefront window to U-value (0.29) and SHGC (0.2)
24.Description: Replace existing window and frame with high performance windows. The U-factor is a measure of thermal transmittance and SHGC stands for Solar Heat Gain Coefficient, values taken as 0.29 Btu/(hÂ·ft2Â·Â°F), SHGC: 0.2. The SHGC and U-factor are 20% below Title 24 values.

25.Name: Replace storefront window to U-value (0.25) and SHGC (0.18)
25.Description: Replace existing window glass and frame with high performance windows by changing the U-factor and SHGC of the window material. The U-factor is a measure of thermal transmittance and SHGC stands for Solar Heat Gain Coefficient, values taken as 0.25 Btu/(hÂ·ft2Â·Â°F), SHGC: 0.18. The SHGC and U-factor are 30% below Title 24 values.

26.Name: Curtain wall replacement  to U-value (0.29) and SHGC (0.2)
26.Description: Replace existing curtain wall with SHGC and U-factor 20% below Title 24 values. The U-factor is a measure of thermal transmittance and SHGC stands for Solar Heat Gain Coefficient, values taken as 0.29 Btu/(hÂ·ft2Â·Â°F), SHGC: 0.2.

27.Name: Curtain wall replacement  to U-value (0.25) and SHGC (0.18)
27.Description: Replace existing curtain wall, with SHGC and U-factor 30% below Title 24 values. The U-factor is a measure of thermal transmittance and SHGC stands for Solar Heat Gain Coefficient, values taken as 0.25 Btu/(hÂ·ft2Â·Â°F), SHGC: 0.18.

28.Name: Apply Top Floor Ceiling Insulation (R30)
28.Description: Install insulation (R30) to the ceiling beneath the existing roof by fasten fiberglass blankets/batts to reduce unwanted heat gain/loss. This measure is most applicable to older vintages and when reroofing is not required (or desired).

29.Name: Apply Top Floor Ceiling Insulation (R38)
29.Description: Install insulation (R38) to the ceiling beneath the existing roof by fasten fiberglass blankets/batts to reduce unwanted heat gain/loss. This measure is most applicable to older vintages and when reroofing is not required (or desired).

30.Name: Add Programmable Thermostat
30.Description: Install programmable thermostat to optimize heating and cooling energy use.

31.Name: Install daylighting sensors for interior lighting control
31.Description: Install photocell with existing timeclock. Daylighting controls function to reduce the light on-time, when natural light is capable of adequately lighting the space. Daylighting methodologies can be applied to any building space with daylight.

32.Name: Install Wall-Mounted Occupancy Sensors
32.Description: Install wall-mounted occupancy sensor pack. Occupancy sensors are motion-sensing devices that can automatically turn on luminaries when motion is detected, keep luminaries on while a space is occupied and turn off luminaries when the space is vacated.

33.Name: Replace Air Filter
33.Description: Replace air filter with low pressure-drop air filter. This can save energy, improve overall air quality and reduce particle build up on internal equipment.

34.Name: Improve Water Tank Insulation
34.Description: Improve insulation for service hot water tank (Fuel type: Natural Gas) to 3.7 W/K

35.Name: Upgrade to Gas Instantaneous Water Heater (0.82)
35.Description: Replace existing service hot water heater with a more efficient gas instantaneous unit with an efficiency of 0.82.

36.Name: Add Ceiling Fan
36.Description: Install ceiling fans to reduce heat destratification. Ceiling fans effectively cool by introducing slow movement to induce evaporative cooling, rather than directly conditioning the air.

37.Name: Replace CAV with VAV for exsiting packaged single zone system
37.Description: Replace existing constant volume control with motorized actuators. Because of the number of replacements and retrofit work involved, this measure is best implemented by replacing existing system with a new unit equipped with Variable Air Volume boxes.

38.Name: Efficiency Upgrade to Electric Storage Water Heater (0.95)
38.Description: Replace existing service hot water heater with more efficient electric storage unit of (0.95).

39.Name: Efficiency Upgrade to Electric Instantaneous Water Heater (0.95)
39.Description: Replace existing service hot water heater with more efficient electric instantaneous unit (0.95).

40.Name: Plug Load Reduction by 10%
40.Description: Examples include unplugging unused equipment, and reducing equipment needs with device sharing (e.g. using one common printer rather than individual ones)

41.Name: Office Computer Power Management (Plug Load Reduction by 5%)
41.Description: Enable computer power management, for example office plug loads reduction by 5%.

42.Name: Night Purge Cycle
42.Description: Implement a night purge cycle to reduce building energy, by cooling the building by using outside night air (no mechanical cooling) prior to building occupation in the mornings.

43.Name: Use Window Shades
43.Description: Close window blinds and drapes to block direct sunshine.

44.Name: Adjust Heating Setpoints to 45 C (113 F)
44.Description: Lower water heater thermostat setpoints to reduce heating energy consumption.

45.Name: Variable Air Volume box - Setpoint Adjustment
45.Description: Lower Variable Air Volume box minimum flow setpoints;

46.Name: Widen zone temperature deadband (cooling: +2 oF; heating: -2 oF)

47.Name: Reduce HVAC equipment runtime
47.Description:
Reduce HVAC equipment runtime, Close Outside Air Damper During
Unoccupied Periods

48.Name: Lighting Retrofit - Motion Sensor and Photocell
48.Description: Replace existing fixture with motion sensor activated model (with photocell)

49.Name: Upgrade to Single-Zone Heat Pump (9.5 EER, 3.2 COP)
49.Description: Replace existing single zone HVAC system with more efficient single-zone, air source heat pump unit

50.Name: Upgrade to Single-Zone Heat Pump (10.6 EER, 3.2 COP)
50.Description: Replace existing single zone HVAC system with more efficient  single-zone, air source heat pump unit

51.Name: Upgrade to Single-Zone Heat Pump (11.0 EER, 3.3 COP)
51.Description: Replace existing single zone HVAC system with more efficient single-zone, air source heat pump unit

52.Name: Economizer Maintenance
52.Description: Check and maintain economizer periodically to maximize system efficiency

53.Name: Photocell Calibration
53.Description: Calibrate photocells to reduce lighting energy consumption

54.Name: Damper Replacement
54.Description: Replace economizer damper to minimize leakage

55.Name: Replace existing Refrigerators with more efficient ones
55.Description: Replace existing refrigerators with more efficient ENERGY STAR model

56.Name: Refrigerant Charge Adjustment (< 20% rated charge)
56.Description: Inspect refrigerant charge and adjust accordingly to optimize system efficiency

57.Name: High Refrigerant Charge Adjustment (>= 20% rated charge)
57.Description: Inspect refrigerant charge and adjust accordingly to optimize system efficiency

58.Name: Clean Coils and Fins
58.Description: Clean cooling and heating coils, and comb heat exchanger fins

59.Name: Repair Economizer
59.Description: verify that the dampers are operating correctly, and that leakage is minimal when the dampers are closed.

60.Name: Upgrade to Heat Pump per Story (9.5 EER, 3.2 COP)
60.Description: Replace existing Multizone HVAC system with more efficient multi-zone, air source heat pump unit for each story

61.Name: Upgrade to Heat Pump per Story (10.6 EER, 3.2 COP)
61.Description: Replace existing Multizone HVAC system with more efficient multi-zone, air source heat pump unit for each story

62.Name: Upgrade to Heat Pump per Stroy (11.0 EER, 3.3 COP)
62.Description: Replace existing Multizone HVAC system with more efficient multi-zone, air source heat pump unit for each story

63.Name: Upgrade to Heat Pump, All Stories (9.5 EER, 3.2 COP)
63.Description: Replace existing Multizone HVAC system with more efficient multi-zone, air source heat pump unit for all stories (9.5 EER and 3.2 COP based on Title 24 for > 20 tons)

64.Name: Upgrade to Heat Pump, All Stories  (10.6 EER, 3.2 COP)
64.Description: Replace existing Multizone HVAC system with more efficient multi-zone, air source heat pump unit for all stories (10.6 EER and 3.2 COP based on Title 24 for 10tons ~ 20 tons)

65.Name: Upgrade to Heat Pump, All Stories  (11.0 EER, 3.3 COP)
65.Description: Replace existing Multizone HVAC system with more efficient multi-zone, air source heat pump unit for all stories  (11.0 EER and 3.3 COP based on Title 24 for < 10tons)

66.Name: Upgrade to VRF System, All Stories (11 EER, 3.3 COP)
66.Description: Replace existing HVAC system with more efficient multi-zone Variable Refrigerant Flow (VRF) System with an energy efficient ratio (EER) of 11 and 3.3 coefficient of performance (COP)(65 kBtu/h ~ 135 kbtu/h); One VRF system is used for all stories

67.Name: Upgrade to VRF System, All Stories (10.6 EER, 3.2 COP)
67.Description: Replace existing HVAC system with more efficient multi-zone Variable Refrigerant Flow (VRF) System with an energy efficient ratio (EER) of 10.6 and 3.2 coefficient of performance (COP) (135 kbtu/h ~ 240 kbtu/h); One VRF system is used for all stories

68.Name: Upgrade to VRF System, All Stories (9.5 EER, 3.2 COP)
68.Description: Replace existing HVAC system with more efficient multi-zone Variable Refrigerant Flow (VRF) System with an energy efficient ratio (EER) of 9.5 and  3.2 coefficient of performance (COP) > 240 kbtu/h; One VRF system is used for all stories

69.Name: Upgrade toVRF System, Single Story (11 EER, 3.3 COP)
69.Description: Replace existing HVAC system with more efficient multi-zone Variable Refrigerant Flow (VRF) System with an energy efficient ratio (EER) of 11 and 3.3 coefficient of performance, (65kbtu/h ~ 135 kbtu/h); One VRF system is used for each story

70.Name: Upgrade to VRF System, Single Story (10.6 EER, 3.2 COP)
70.Description: Replace existing HVAC system with more efficient multi-zone Variable Refrigerant Flow (VRF) System with an energy efficient ratio (EER) of 10.6 and 3.2 coefficient of performance, (135kBtu/h ~ 240 kBtu/h); One VRF system is used for each story

71.Name: Upgrade to VRF System, Single Story (9.5 EER, 3.2 COP)
71.Description: Replace existing HVAC system with more efficient multi-zone Variable Refrigerant Flow (VRF) System with an energy efficient ratio (EER) of 9.5 and 3.2 coefficient of performance > 240 kBtu/h; One VRF system is used for each story

72.Name: Upgrade to heat pump water heater (COP 3.3)
72.Description: Replace existing service hot water tank to heat pump water heater with COP 3.3

73.Name: Add Demand Controlled Ventilation with CO2 Sensors
73.Description: Install CO2 sensor, one per zone, to enable demand controlled ventilation

74.Name: Replace CAV with VAV for packaged single zone heat pump system
74.Description: Replace existing constant volume control with motorized actuators. Because of the number of replacements and retrofit work involved, this measure is best implemented by replacing existing system with a new unit equipped with Variable Air Volume (VAV) boxes for packaged single zone heat pump system

75.Name: Replace RTUs with Units that Use Evaporative Cooling
75.Description: Replace RTUs with Units that Use Evaporative Cooling

76.Name: Install an Energy Recovery Ventilator (ERV)
76.Description: Install Energy Recovery Ventilator (ERV) for heat and humidity recovery

77.Name: Install a desiccant wheel dehumidification system
77.Description: Install a desiccant wheel dehumidification system

79.Name: Cooling tower â€“ condenser water temperature reset
79.Description: Cooling tower â€“ condenser water temperature reset

80.Name: Replace constant speed pumps to variable speed pumps
80.Description: Replace constant speed pumps to variable speed pumps

81.Name: Replace to high efficiency AHU fans (65%)
81.Description: Replace to high efficiency AHU fans (65%)

82.Name: Lower VAV Box Minimum Flow Setpoints (25%)
82.Description: Lower VAV Box Minimum Flow Setpoints (Rebalance Pneumatic Boxes) (25%)
